cross.translation[0].definitions[0].sign: go from one side to another
cross.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to go or stretch from one side of something such as a road, river, room etc to the other
cross.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: An old bridge crosses the river.
It’s easy to have an accident just crossing the road.
He was hit by a car when he tried to cross over the road near Euston station.
the first steamship to cross the Atlantic
She crossed over to sit beside Dot.
cross.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if you cross a line, track etc, you go over and beyond it
cross.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He raised his arms in triumph as he crossed the line for his 100-metres win.
cross.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if two or more roads, lines, etc cross, or if one crosses another, they go across each other
cross.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The by-pass crosses Wilton Lane shortly after a roundabout.
cross.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if you cross your legs, arms, or ankles, you put one on top of the other
cross.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She was sitting on the floor with her legs crossed.
cross.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to mix two or more different breeds of animal or plant to form a new breed
cross.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: a flower produced by crossing several different varieties
These cattle were crossed with a breed from the highlands.
cross.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to make someone angry by opposing their plans or orders
cross.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: He hated anyone who crossed him.
cross.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to kick, throw, or hit the ball across the playing area in a sport such as football, hockey etc
cross.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to draw two lines across a cheque to show that it must be paid into the bank account of the person whose name is on it
cross.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if two letters about the same subject cross in the post, each was sent before the other was received
cross.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a mixture of two things, breeds, or qualities
cross.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The tour manager’s role is a cross between hostess and courier.
Their dog is a cross between two well-known breeds.
cross.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a mark (x or +) used on paper, to represent where something is, or where something should be
cross.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: I’ve put a cross on the map to mark where our street is.
Please sign your name by the cross.
cross.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a mark (x) used on paper to show that something that has been written or printed is not correct
cross.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: My homework got a lot more ticks than crosses.
cross.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a mark (x or +) used by someone who cannot write, in order to sign their name
cross.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: the cross that Jesus Christ died on
cross.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Christians believe that Jesus died on the cross for our sins.
cross.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: an object, picture, or mark in the shape of a cross, used as a sign of the Christian faith or for decoration
cross.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: Pauline wore a tiny gold cross.
cross.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: an upright post of wood with another crossing it near the top, that people in the past were fastened to with nails and left to die on as a punishment
cross.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: a decoration in the shape of a cross that is given to someone as an honour, especially for military courage
cross.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: He was awarded the George Cross.
cross.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: a kick or hit of the ball in a sport such as football, hockey etc, that goes across the field
cross.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: a way of hitting someone in the sport of boxing, in which your arm goes over theirs as they try to hit you
cross.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: He caught his opponent with a right cross to the chin.
cross.translation[1].definitions[10].def: if you describe something as the cross that someone has to bear, you mean it is a problem that makes them very unhappy or worried, and that continues for a long time
cross.translation[1].definitions[10].exa: I feel sorry for you, but we all have our crosses to bear.
cross.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: She gets cross when he goes out drinking.
Sometimes I get very cross with the children.
She was cross at being interrupted.
cross.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: going from one side to the other
cross.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: a cross-Channel ferry  (=sailing from Britain to France)
cross.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: going between two things and joining them
cross.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to draw two lines and write the words ‘account payee’ on a cheque, showing that it can only be paid into a bank account of the person named on the cheque, and not exchanged for cash or paid into a different account
